title: Barista work a craft, not just a job - Invercargill businesses
text:
Barista work a craft, not just a job - Invercargill businesses AMBER-LEIGH WOOLF Last updated 13:24, February 19 2017 JOHN HAWKINS/FAIRFAX NZ 
Viking Coffee owners Markus and Maria Hirner at Global Byte cafe, where they are also managers. Markus and Maria launched Viking Coffee last year and plan to open a public roastery in Invercargill. 
An Invercargill business couple have launched a coffee roasting venture to fill what they call a need in the city for quality, speciality coffee. 
Viking Coffee owners Markus and Maria Hirner are looking for an Invercargill premises for a public roastery and hope to start training new baristas. 
Markus said changing perceptions of barista work as "just another job" could improve New Zealand coffee. SUPPLIED 
ROAR coffee co-director Steve Taylor and head roaster and company director Kelly Taylor. 
"In Germany, Sweden, some states in America and Australia, they have got training facilities there and they consider it as a career option. 
READ MORE: 
"In New Zealand I think we feel that it's just another job," he said. 
Invercargill needed to support its hospitality culture, he said. 
"We need to be a bit more of a thriving hub, and to get some noise going on." 
The couple noticed the city had no speciality coffee roasters and started Viking Coffee in a private premises in August last year. 
They also manage Global Byte cafe. Ad Feedback 
When Bill Richardson Transport World's cafe The Grille and Meccaspresso Cafe opened, city activity soared, Markus said. 
People seemed to be getting out and about more and Global Byte had more customers through the door. 
"My drive was I wanted something better in coffee," Markus said. 
"We were at the point where we said, "We need to advance this in Invercargill'." 
There was a "100 per cent" gap in the speciality coffee market in the city, Markus said. 
They noticed a migration of Aucklanders to Invercargill, which they said could be because of cheaper housing. 
"We definitely notice the people from further away, they know coffee really well, and they can tell the difference." 
Within six months they hope to open a public roastery, which could double as a training ground for new baristas. 
"We find in Invercargill that it's hard to find baristas. We often have to get them from out of town." 
Auckland, Wellington and Dunedin were the coffee hubs, and the regions needed to catch up, Markus said. 
ROAR coffee head roaster and company director Kelly Taylor said she too saw the need for locally roasted and supplied coffee in Southland. 
"Anyone can distribute coffee but when it's the roaster that's personally delivering it and coming to say hi, it's about building relationships and looking after each other." 
There was room for improvement in the region's barista training, she said. 
"It's often lacking because it's sometimes not considered to be as important as it needs to be," she said. 
"Successful cafes employ the right people who create the passion around their coffee." 
In terms of quality coffee, Southland was starting to align with other parts of New Zealand. 
"Now that the quality product is becoming available and readily supplied locally, it's up to the consumer to also demand more from their cup." 
Industry and Batch cafe co-owner Donna Hamilton said they trained all of their baristas in-house, which would take about six months full-time on the coffee machine. 
She said getting the right barista in Invercargill depended on whether the person had passion. 
"But it can take a long, long time to find that spark," Hamilton said. 
"People under-value them, it's an amazing profession." 
Hamilton said Invercargill's coffee scene was no better or worse than other places. 
"No matter what city you go to, there's good coffee and bad coffee," she said. 
"Invercargill people really appreciate good coffee and they know what good coffee is." 
Invercargill was growing, getting busier, and new cafes were opening, she said. 
"We should be proud of it."
